maml:description.maml:para: Adds a secret to the personal vault store.

This cmdlet adds the given name and secret value to the personal vault. It auto generates a key of 32 bits and encrypts the secret value and store it in the vault. You can also generate a new key or bring your own key and add the kv pair to the store.

maml:Description.maml:para: Name to store against the secret value. For instance an user name.
This denotes the secret value to be stored.
32 bits key to encrypt the secret value
Provide the details of what you are storing
32 bits key to encrypt the secret value
Name to store against the secret value. For instance an user name.
This denotes the secret value to be stored.
Provide the details of what you are storing

maml:alert.maml:para: The secret values that you are entering as plain text in the session will not stick to in the history. PersonalVault will automatically remove the module related cmdlets from the history. Re-open the console to make sure that all the secrets are removed from the history.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
# You should register first to work with the vault # You should remember your recovery word to recover your registered username and password PS C:\> $recoveryWord = Read-Host -AsSecureString PS C:\> Register-PSPersonalVault -Credential (Get-Credential) -RecoveryWord $recoveryWord
# connect to the vault with the credential PS C:\> $connection = Connect-PSPersonalVault -Credential (Get-Credential)
# add secrets to the vault PS C:\> Add-PSSecret -Name "GMail_username" -Value "Thisisanonhackablepassword@2021" -Metadata "My personal gmail account."

dev:remarks.maml:para: Add a secret value to the vault.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Add-PSSecret -Name Test -Value 'Test@123' -Metadata "Adding a test value" WARNING: Secret 'Test@123' was hacked 833 time(s); Consider changing the secret value.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get a warning if the secret value that you are trying to add is exposed.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a connection to the vault.
Creates a connection to the vault. It returns the connection object after creating a connection. It won't verify if your credential are correct, you will only know when you run any cmdlet.

maml:Description.maml:para: Pass the registered credential to connect to the vault successfully.
Pass the registered credential to connect to the vault successfully.

maml:alert.maml:para: The secret values that you are entering as plain text in the session will not stick to in the history. PersonalVault will automatically remove the module related cmdlets from the history. Re-open the console to make sure that all the secrets are removed from the history.

maml:description.maml:para: Get the archived keys.
This cmdlet retrives the archived keys which are separated by date modified timestamp. Optionally you can get the archived keys by providing the modified date.

maml:Description.maml:para: Specify the date that the key was modified.
Specify the date that the key was modified.

maml:alert.maml:para: The secret values that you are entering as plain text in the session will not stick to in the history. PersonalVault will automatically remove the module related cmdlets from the history. Re-open the console to make sure that all the secrets are removed from the history.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
# You should register first to work with the vault # You should remember your recovery word to recover your registered username and password PS C:\> $recoveryWord = Read-Host -AsSecureString PS C:\> Register-PSPersonalVault -Credential (Get-Credential) -RecoveryWord $recoveryWord
# connect to the vault with the credential PS C:\> $connection = Connect-PSPersonalVault -Credential (Get-Credential)
PS C:\> Get-PSArchivedKeys DateModified Key ------------ --- 04/06/2020 10:34:44 Key1 04/06/2020 10:37:06 Key2 10/07/2020 10:39:27 Key3 10/09/2021 10:39:29 Key4

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-PSArchivedKeys -DateModified (Get-Date 04/06/2020) DateModified Key ------------ --- 04/06/2020 10:34:44 Key1 04/06/2020 10:37:06 Key2

dev:remarks.maml:para: Lists all the archived keys from the specified date.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the key if it exists or generates a new key.
Gets the key if it exists or generates a new key. You can use the Force parameter to rotate the keys and secure your secret with different keys.

maml:Description.maml:para: If true rotates the key.
If true rotates the key.

maml:alert.maml:para: The secret values that you are entering as plain text in the session will not stick to in the history. PersonalVault will automatically remove the module related cmdlets from the history. Re-open the console to make sure that all the secrets are removed from the history.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
# You should register first to work with the vault # You should remember your recovery word to recover your registered username and password PS C:\> $recoveryWord = Read-Host -AsSecureString PS C:\> Register-PSPersonalVault -Credential (Get-Credential) -RecoveryWord $recoveryWord
# connect to the vault with the credential PS C:\> $connection = Connect-PSPersonalVault -Credential (Get-Credential)
PS C:\> Get-PSKey Key1

maml:description.maml:para: Get the key and secret in a key value pair.
Get the key and encrypted secret in a key value pair. Tab complete the Name and retrieve the secret associated with it. To get the secret as plain text enable the switch AsPlaintext.

maml:Description.maml:para: Pass the key to decrypt.
If true gets the secret value as plain text
Provide the name to get it's associated secret value.
If true gets the secret value as plain text
Pass the key to decrypt.
Provide the name to get it's associated secret value.

maml:alert.maml:para: The secret values that you are entering as plain text in the session will not stick to in the history. PersonalVault will automatically remove the module related cmdlets from the history. Re-open the console to make sure that all the secrets are removed from the history.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
# You should register first to work with the vault # You should remember your recovery word to recover your registered username and password PS C:\> $recoveryWord = Read-Host -AsSecureString PS C:\> Register-PSPersonalVault -Credential (Get-Credential) -RecoveryWord $recoveryWord
# connect to the vault with the credential PS C:\> $connection = Connect-PSPersonalVault -Credential (Get-Credential)
PS C:\> Get-PSSecret Name Value ---- ----- Test 76492d1116743f0423413b16050a5345MgB8AHQAMQBCAE0AWQBHAG0AYgAzAGQAdwBMAEwAaAB1... MynewSecret 76492d1116743f0423413b16050a5345MgB8AGIAVQBrAG4AUgBYAHIAQQBtAFgANQBIAEcAMwBu...

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get the available secrets from the store.
Get the secret associated with the key.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-PSSecret -Name Test -Key Key1 -AsPlainText Test@123

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get the secret associated with the key by passing the key that was used to encrypt it.

maml:description.maml:para: Recovers the registered username and password.
Recovers the resgistered username and password. You should pass the recovery word to successfully recover the username and password.

maml:Description.maml:para: Recovery word to retrieve the registered credential.
Recovery word to retrieve the registered credential.

maml:alert.maml:para: The secret values that you are entering as plain text in the session will not stick to in the history. PersonalVault will automatically remove the module related cmdlets from the history. Re-open the console to make sure that all the secrets are removed from the history.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $recoveryWord = Read-Host -AsSecureString PS C:\> Import-PSPersonalVault $recoveryWord

dev:remarks.maml:para: Returns username and password that was registered to access the vault.

maml:description.maml:para: Registers credential to access the vault.
Registers credential to access the vault.

maml:Description.maml:para: Pass the user name and password and register to access the vault.
Recovery word to recover the username and password incase if you forget.
If true overwrites the existing stored credential
Pass the user name and password and register to access the vault.
If true overwrites the existing stored credential
Recovery word to recover the username and password incase if you forget.

maml:alert.maml:para: The secret values that you are entering as plain text in the session will not stick to in the history. PersonalVault will automatically remove the module related cmdlets from the history. Re-open the console to make sure that all the secrets are removed from the history.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: # You should register first to work with the vault # You should remember your recovery word to recover your registered username and password PS C:\> $recoveryWord = Read-Host -AsSecureString PS C:\> Register-PSPersonalVault -Credential (Get-Credential) -RecoveryWord $recoveryWord

dev:remarks.maml:para: Registers the credential to access the vault.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes the personal vault.
Permanently removes the personal vault. This is a destructive operation and if used all the stored secrets will be lost.

maml:Description.maml:para: Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Permanently removes the vault if true.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Permanently removes the vault if true.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

maml:alert.maml:para: The secret values that you are entering as plain text in the session will not stick to in the history. PersonalVault will automatically remove the module related cmdlets from the history. Re-open the console to make sure that all the secrets are removed from the history.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
# You should register first to work with the vault # You should remember your recovery word to recover your registered username and password PS C:\> $recoveryWord = Read-Host -AsSecureString PS C:\> Register-PSPersonalVault -Credential (Get-Credential) -RecoveryWord $recoveryWord
# connect to the vault with the credential PS C:\> $connection = Connect-PSPersonalVault -Credential (Get-Credential)
PS C:\> Remove-PSPersonalVault -Force

maml:description.maml:para: Removes the existing connection and stored connection to the vault.
Removes the existing connection and stored connection to the vault.

maml:Description.maml:para: Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
If true removes the store credential used for connecting the vault.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
If true removes the store credential used for connecting the vault.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

maml:alert.maml:para: The secret values that you are entering as plain text in the session will not stick to in the history. PersonalVault will automatically remove the module related cmdlets from the history. Re-open the console to make sure that all the secrets are removed from the history.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
# You should register first to work with the vault # You should remember your recovery word to recover your registered username and password PS C:\> $recoveryWord = Read-Host -AsSecureString PS C:\> Register-PSPersonalVault -Credential (Get-Credential) -RecoveryWord $recoveryWord
# connect to the vault with the credential PS C:\> $connection = Connect-PSPersonalVault -Credential (Get-Credential)
PS C:\> Remove-PSPersonalVaultConnection -Force

dev:remarks.maml:para: You must create a connection to the vault before removing the connection. If you remove the connection you have to register before connecting.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes a secret value associated with the given key name.
Removes a secret value associated with the given key name.

maml:Description.maml:para: Provide the name
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
If true permanently removes the value.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
If true permanently removes the value.
Provide the name
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

maml:alert.maml:para: The secret values that you are entering as plain text in the session will not stick to in the history. PersonalVault will automatically remove the module related cmdlets from the history. Re-open the console to make sure that all the secrets are removed from the history.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
# You should register first to work with the vault # You should remember your recovery word to recover your registered username and password PS C:\> $recoveryWord = Read-Host -AsSecureString PS C:\> Register-PSPersonalVault -Credential (Get-Credential) -RecoveryWord $recoveryWord
# connect to the vault with the credential PS C:\> $connection = Connect-PSPersonalVault -Credential (Get-Credential)
PS C:\> Remove-PSSecret -Name Test -Force

dev:remarks.maml:para: Removes the secret value for given name test.

maml:description.maml:para: Updates the secret value for given key and value pair.
Updates the secret value for given key and value pair. Tab complete the Name parameter to identify and update the secret value.

maml:Description.maml:para: Name for the secret value.
Provide the secret value.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
If true updates the secret value for given name.
Provide the key to encrypt the value.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
If true updates the secret value for given name.
Provide the key to encrypt the value.
Name for the secret value.
Provide the secret value.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

maml:alert.maml:para: The secret values that you are entering as plain text in the session will not stick to in the history. PersonalVault will automatically remove the module related cmdlets from the history. Re-open the console to make sure that all the secrets are removed from the history.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
# You should register first to work with the vault # You should remember your recovery word to recover your registered username and password PS C:\> $recoveryWord = Read-Host -AsSecureString PS C:\> Register-PSPersonalVault -Credential (Get-Credential) -RecoveryWord $recoveryWord
# connect to the vault with the credential PS C:\> $connection = Connect-PSPersonalVault -Credential (Get-Credential)
PS C:\> Update-PSSecret -Name Test -Value StrongPassword -Force

dev:remarks.maml:para: Updates the value for the given name Test.
